Award.AwardTitle: WSC-Category 1: From natural wetland to murky water: Cross-disciplinary analysis of a drowning urbanized coast

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate driven sea-level rise and an intensified hydrological cycle are threatening water resources in the New Orleans metropolitan area and surrounding Mississippi River Delta. Variable river discharge and sea level rise can promote cycles of degradation by increasing flooding potential and salinity in regional waterways. Reversing the onset or progression of degradation will involve managing freshwater supply (including reintroduction of freshwater and sediment into wetlands), enabling the sequestration of nutrients that can potentially restore highly valued habitat, and removal of toxins that challenge human and ecosystem health. Science and engineering alone will not be sufficient to implement effective management plans. Well-defined policy and legal frameworks will be essential for progressive management interventions. Similarly, engaging local stakeholders to enhance awareness of concerns about water sustainability will be necessary to ensure ecological and community resiliency under future climate conditions.

The purposes of this incubation project are to develop a strong organizational framework, to enhance existing research capacity and infrastructure, and to obtain critical baseline data that will set the stage for the development of a comprehensive understanding of water quality and management issues in the Mississippi River Delta region. A demonstration project illustrates integrative coastal water management in the study area. This project focuses on management of water quality in an urban-influenced wetland hydrologic system. The research team assesses government jurisdiction and property rights related to data on historical and current water and environmental conditions. The research provides a baseline understanding of water quality issues at the study site. The study also use focus groups consisting of local stakeholders to collect data on the historical context and perceptions of environmental change and to inform the development of tenable policy solutions. These efforts involve a working group composed of experts and community partners. The goals of the working group are to enhance water resources data management to promote institutional management and community awareness in the proposed study area, and to identify key challenges and priority research areas that are most likely to offer practical solutions for water sustainability in vulnerable coastal environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project objective was to understand water sustainability in low-lying, urbanized coastal regions responding to stressors such as accelerated sea-level rise, subsidence, changing river discharge regimes and nutrient loading, that result in degradation of coastal ecosystems and increased vulnerability of urban environments and cultures. Such concerns represent environmental problems of global significance because low-lying urbanized coasts worldwide face similar challenges. We sought to develop novel perspectives and frameworks for sustaining water quality and availability for southern Louisiana, which represents a natural laboratory already experiencing water quality issues owing to sea level rise. Environmental experts met to address key aspects of water quality and availability in coastal zones. A research project was initiated to develop effective approaches for addressing key challenges to water sustainability in the study region. The project also sought to understand: (1) the stakeholder communities’ sense of place and history of environmental and social change; and (2) how local knowledge can be employed for adaptive management of water resources and the protection of vital ecosystem services.

In pursuit of these goals, we set up focus groups to help identify the ecosystem services provided by the New Orleans urban-wetland ecosystem; explain how past decisions and historical actions have affected the condition of ecosystem services; understand relationships among sea-level rise and coastal erosion in southern Louisiana; identify resident perceptions pertaining to current threats, risks, and vulnerabilities to hazards; and identify future ecosystem management scenarios for the resilience and sustainability of the region. The focus groups focused on three chief areas of inquiry. First, key community leaders were queried on their experiences regarding developments since Hurricane Katrina, including the Bayou Bienvenue platform, small-scale restoration initiatives, and federal/state restoration proposals. We were curious to understand how these community leader viewed the concepts of “sustainability” and “resilience,” and how the respondents understand and use these terms in their collective sense-making and discursive framing practices. Second, we engaged with long-time residents of the Bayou Bienvenue area, asking questions about their understanding of how social and land-use changes, maritime development, and urban development have impacted the ecological conditions in the bayou. Finally, we approached organizers and activists in the environmental community who have developed programming related to Bayou Bienvenue since the devastation caused by the collapse of the Army Corps of Engineers’ levee system following Hurricane Katrina. We asked these respondents about how and why they became involved in environmental activism and material interventions around a space like the Bayou Triangle and the Lower Ninth Ward neighborhood.

Our approach included evaluation of the unique legal issues related to Bayou Bienvenue, in particular, and the flooding of coastal property owing to rising sea level, in general. Here, we sought to facilitate a better under understanding of the “legal landscape” that comes into play when planning for the resilience and sustainability of urban and coastal ecosystems. This work requires detailed understanding of the interface between the law and the natural environment. To better address this complex legal landscape, three areas of importance to the project that were investigated.
